qas.question: What needs to be isolated from infected tissue to provide a biochemical diagnosis of an infectious disease?
What enzyme's presence is characteristic of specific types of viral infections?
What does the protein hemagglutinin bind together?
Why are the presence of certain enymzes a tell tale sign of a virus?

answers.text: humans can make neither RNA replicases nor reverse transcriptase

qas.question: What needs to be combined with infected tissue to provide a biochemical diagnosis of an infectious disease?
What enzyme's absence is characteristic of specific types of viral infections?
What does the protein hemagglutinin pull apart?

plausible_answers.text: the presence of these enzymes are characteristic of specific types of viral infections

qas.question: Why are the presence of certain enzymes a sign of good health?

context: The isolation of <a0_0><b4_0>enzymes<b4_0/><a0_0/> from infected tissue can also provide the basis of a biochemical diagnosis of an infectious disease. For example, <a3_0>humans can make neither <a1_0><b5_0>RNA replicases<b5_0/><a1_0/> nor reverse transcriptase<a3_0/>, and <b7_0>the presence of these enzymes are characteristic of specific types of viral infections<b7_0/>. The ability of the viral protein hemagglutinin to bind <a2_0><b6_0>red blood cells<b6_0/><a2_0/> together into a detectable matrix may also be characterized as a biochemical test for viral infection, although strictly speaking hemagglutinin is not an enzyme and has no metabolic function.
